0.93.text:
The President:
It's great to be back in New Hampshire.

4.30.text:
I have to say, though, that most
of my memories of this state are cold.

11.47.text:
So it's good
to be here in August.

14.67.text:
There are a couple of people
that I want to acknowledge who

17.03.text:
are here today,
some special guests.

19.20.text:
First of all, I want to thank
principal Jeffrey Collins,

22.10.text:
and the Portsmouth students
and faculty and staff.

25.97.text:
Thank you
-- our host for today.

Your own outstanding

wife, Dr. Susan Lynch is here,

40.73.text: the First Lady of New Hampshire.

45.93.text:
Your United States

59.63.text:
The governor of

61.47.text:
and we are glad he's here

73.90.text:
Two of my favorite people, they
are just taking Congress by

81.23.text:
Carol Shea-Porter -- give

92.57.text:
And we've got your
own mayor, Tom Ferrini is here.

105.23.text:
Now, I want to
thank more than anybody, Lori,

109.47.text:
for that introduction, and for

121.20.text:
Lori's story is the same kind of
story that I've read in letters,

125.10.text:
that I've heard in town hall
meetings just like this one for

130.03.text:
In fact, some of you were in

132.53.text:
hall meetings, as I was

135.17.text:
It's the story of hardworking
Americans who are held hostage

139.53.text:
by health insurance companies
that deny them coverage,

142.60.text:
or drop their coverage, or
charge fees that they can't

145.40.text:
afford for care that
they desperately need.

151.80.text:
It is bankrupting
families and businesses,

154.13.text:
and that's why we are going to
pass health insurance reform in 2009.

172.67.text:
Now, this is obviously a tough
time for families here in

175.63.text:
New Hampshire and all
across America.

178.47.text:
Six months ago, we were in the
middle of the worst recession of our lifetimes.

185.27.text:
I want you to remember what
things were like in January and February.

188.50.text:
We were losing about
700,000 jobs per month.

194.27.text:
And economists of all stripes
feared a second-coming of the

199.83.text: That was only six months ago.

202.43.text:
That's why we acted as fast as
we could to pass a Recovery Act

208.77.text:
And I want to make sure
everybody understands what we did.

213.70.text:
One-third of the money in the
Recovery Act went to tax cuts

217.73.text:
that have already started
showing up in the paychecks of

220.70.text:
about 500,000 working families
in New Hampshire --

229.53.text:
We also cut taxes for small
businesses on the investments

232.50.text:
that they make, and over 300 New
Hampshire small businesses have

237.07.text:
qualified for new loans
backed by the Recovery Act.

241.00.text:
Now, that was a third -- that
was a third of the Recovery Act.

245.30.text:
Another third of the money
in the Recovery Act is for

248.83.text:
emergency relief for folks
who've borne the brunt of this recession.

253.87.text:
So we've extended
unemployment benefits for

264.40.text:
We've made health
insurance 65 percent cheaper for

268.03.text:
families who rely on COBRA
while they're looking for work.

277.00.text:
And for states that
were facing historic budget

279.30.text:
shortfalls, we provided
assistance that has saved the

282.10.text:
jobs of tens of thousands of
workers who provided essential

284.97.text:
services -- like teachers
and police officers.

290.57.text:
So it's prevented
a lot of painful cuts in the

294.17.text:
state, but also a lot of painful
state and local tax increases.

299.33.text:
Now, the last third of the
Recovery Act is for investments

302.03.text:
that are already putting
people back to work.

304.37.text:
These are jobs refurbishing
bridges and pavement on I-95;

309.70.text:
or jobs at the community health

315.27.text:
will be able to add
nurses, and extend hours,

317.90.text:
and serve up to
500 new patients.

320.87.text:
These are good jobs doing
the work America needs done.

323.97.text:
And, by the way, most of the
work is being done by private,

327.00.text:
local businesses, because that's
how we're going to grow this economy again.

331.37.text:
So there is no doubt that the
Recovery Act has helped put the

337.07.text:
We just saw last Friday the job
picture is beginning to turn.

341.53.text:
We're starting to see signs that
business investment is coming back.

345.93.text:
But, New Hampshire, that doesn't
mean we're out of the woods,

349.73.text:
It doesn't mean we can just sit
back and do nothing while so

355.23.text:
because even before this
recession hit we had an economy

358.60.text:
that was working pretty well
for the wealthiest Americans,

362.93.text:
it was working pretty well
for Wall Street bankers,

366.10.text:
it was working pretty
well for big corporations,

but it wasn't working so

It was an economy of

373.90.text:
And we can't go back to

376.83.text:
If we want this country to

and if we want our children to
succeed in the 21st century --

383.50.text:
then we're going to have to take
the steps necessary to lay a new

391.80.text:
We need to build an economy
that works for everybody,

408.73.text:
Now, health insurance reform is
one of those pillars that we

413.63.text:
need to build up
that new foundation.

417.27.text:
I don't have to explain to you
that nearly 46 million Americans

423.43.text:
don't have health
insurance coverage today.

426.60.text:
In the wealthiest
nation on Earth,

46 million of our fellow

433.63.text:
If something happens,
they go bankrupt,

or they don't get

But it's just as important that

reform for the Americans who

452.70.text:
-- because right now

454.80.text:
that too often works better for

459.37.text: And we've got to change that.

516.90.text:
That's the health care

insurance companies because

Either the insurance company

or they dropped their coverage

554.90.text:

559.80.text:
condition, or they charged
higher premiums and

565.93.text:
No one holds these companies

And I have to say, this is

577.00.text:
I talked about this when I was

I will never forget

581.13.text:
as she fought cancer

her insurance would refuse to

588.73.text:
And by the way, this was because

595.20.text:
when she took her new job --
even though it hadn't been

601.00.text:

610.40.text:
One woman testified that an
insurance company would not

612.83.text:

They're only

652.63.text: That is going to be a priority.

insurance companies will be

671.03.text:
because of a person's

They will not be able

Your health insurance

And it will be when

insurance companies will no

722.17.text:
And we will place a limit on

739.20.text:
And finally -- this is important

756.73.text:

That makes sense,

If you do

company giveaways in Medicare

Now, before I start

New Hampshire, I was up here
